title: How to Season Tilapia

steps.headline: Melt 1/4 cup (56 g) of butter.
steps.description: Put the butter into a small saucepan and heat it on low until it melts. If you prefer, you can put the butter into a microwave-safe dish and heat it until it melts. Use unsalted butter so you can control the seasoning of the fish.

steps.headline: Zest 1 lemon and squeeze the juice.
steps.description: Use a microplane or side of a box grater to remove the zest from 1 lemon. Then slice the lemon in half and squeeze enough juice to measure 2 tablespoons (30 ml).

steps.headline: Whisk the butter, lemon juice, zest, and garlic.
steps.description: Put the lemon juice and zest into the bowl or saucepan with the melted butter. Add 3 cloves of minced garlic and whisk the sauce until it's combined.

steps.headline: Pour the sauce over the tilapia.
steps.description: Lay 4 tilapia fillets in a large baking dish and pour the lemon-butter garlic sauce over them. Use a pan that's large enough to fit the fish in a single layer.

steps.headline: Bake the fish in a 425 °F (218 °C) oven for 10 to 12 minutes.
steps.description: Preheat the oven before you put the pan in the oven. Bake the fish until it flakes and is cooked throughout. To serve the fish, ladle a little of the sauce that's left in the bottom of the pan over the fish. Store the leftover tilapia in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 or 4 days.

steps.headline: Mix all of the spices to make the rub.
steps.description:
Get out a small bowl and put all of the blackening spices into it. You'll need to whisk together:
3 tablespoons (21 g) of paprika
1 teaspoon (5.5 g) of salt
1 tablespoons (7 g) of onion powder
1 teaspoon (2 g) of black pepper
1/4 to 1 teaspoon (0.5 to 2 g) of cayenne pepper to taste
1 teaspoon (1.5 g) of thyme
1 teaspoon (1.5 g) of oregano
1/2 teaspoon (1.5 g) of garlic powder

steps.headline: Brush the tilapia with olive oil and put it in a pan.
steps.description: Get out 2 pounds (0.91 kg) of tilapia and dip a pastry brush in olive oil. Spread the oil over both sides of the tilapia and lay it in the baking dish or grill basket. The oil will help the blackening rub stick to the fish.

steps.headline: Coat the fish with the rub.
steps.description: Sprinkle the blackening seasoning over the fish and then turn it over. Use your hands to rub the seasoning into the fish. If you only want to cook 1 pound (0.45 kg) of tilapia, you won't need to use all of the seasoning. Store the leftover seasoning in an airtight container in the pantry for up to 6 months.

steps.headline: Bake the blackened tilapia in the oven or on the grill.
steps.description: If you'd like to bake the fish, place it in a baking dish and cook it at 425 °F (218 °C) for 10 to 12 minutes. If you'd rather grill the fish, put it in a grill basket and set it on a hot grill. Grill the tilapia for 4 minutes, turning it halfway. Refrigerate leftover tilapia in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 or 4 days.

steps.headline: Slice the almonds and grate Parmesan cheese.
steps.description: Put 1/3 cup (35 g) of sliced almonds onto a cutting board and chop them finely. Get out a wedge of Parmesan cheese and use a box grater to grate 3 tablespoons (15 g) of cheese. Put the almonds and cheese into a bowl. If you don't have a wedge of cheese, you can use pre-grated cheese but the flavor won't be as intense.

steps.headline: Mix the almonds and cheese with bread crumbs and spices.
steps.description: Put 1/4 cup (25 g) of plain dry bread crumbs into the bowl with the cheese and almonds. Then stir in 1/2 teaspoon (1.5 g) of garlic powder, 1/2 teaspoon (3.5 g) of paprika, 1/2 teaspoon (0.2 g) of parsley flakes, and 1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of black pepper. If you don't have bread crumbs, try using crushed crackers.

steps.headline: Brush the tilapia with oil and put it in a baking dish.
steps.description: Get out 1 pound (0.45 kg) of tilapia and dip a pastry brush in olive oil. Brush both sides of the fish with the oil. The oil will help the breading stick to the fish.

steps.headline: Coat the fish with breading.
steps.description: Lay the fillets into the Parmesan herb breading and turn the pieces over. Ensure that every part of the fillet is covered with the breading. You may need to press gently to get the breading to stick to the fish.

steps.headline: Bake the tilapia at 450 °F (232 °C) for 10 to 12 minutes.
steps.description: Place the breaded tilapia into a baking dish and put it in a preheated oven. Bake the fish until the breading becomes crispy and the fish flakes easily with a fork. Store leftover tilapia in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 or 4 days. Keep in mind that it will become soft the longer it's stored.

steps.headline: Zest 1 lemon and chop the fresh herbs.
steps.description:
Use a microplane or side of a box grater to zest a lemon. Place 3/4 cup (20 g) of fresh herbs on your cutting board and chop them fine. Consider using a mixture of:
Parsley
Thyme
Mint
Chives
Cilantro

steps.headline: Mix the herbs, zest, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Put the lemon zest and chopped herbs into a bowl. Stir in 3/4 teaspoon (4 g) of salt and 1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of black pepper. If you'd like to make the seasoning in advance, put it in an airtight container and freeze it for up to 3 months.

steps.headline: Coat the tilapia with the seasoning.
steps.description: Get out 4 tilapia fillets and cover each side with the herb seasoning. Use your fingers to gently press the herbs into the fish. Be gentle as you handle the fish because you don't want it to fall apart.

steps.headline: Sauté the fish for 4 minutes.
steps.description: Place the fish in a skillet and pan-fry it over medium heat for 4 minutes. Turn the fish halfway through the cooking time so they cook evenly. Serve the fish immediately with a green salad and crusty bread. If you prefer, place the fish in a baking dish and cook them in the oven instead. Bake the fish at 450 °F (232 °C) for 10 to 12 minutes. Refrigerate the leftover fish in an airtight container for up to 3 or 4 days.

text:
Lemon-Butter Garlic Sauce Melt 1/4 cup (56 g) of butter. Put the butter into a small saucepan and heat it on low until it melts. If you prefer, you can put the butter into a microwave-safe dish and heat it until it melts. Use unsalted butter so you can control the seasoning of the fish. Zest 1 lemon and squeeze the juice. Use a microplane or side of a box grater to remove the zest from 1 lemon. Then slice the lemon in half and squeeze enough juice to measure 2 tablespoons (30 ml). Whisk the butter, lemon juice, zest, and garlic. Put the lemon juice and zest into the bowl or saucepan with the melted butter. Add 3 cloves of minced garlic and whisk the sauce until it's combined. Pour the sauce over the tilapia. Lay 4 tilapia fillets in a large baking dish and pour the lemon-butter garlic sauce over them. Use a pan that's large enough to fit the fish in a single layer. Bake the fish in a 425 °F (218 °C) oven for 10 to 12 minutes. Preheat the oven before you put the pan in the oven. Bake the fish until it flakes and is cooked throughout. To serve the fish, ladle a little of the sauce that's left in the bottom of the pan over the fish. Store the leftover tilapia in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 or 4 days. Blackening Rub Mix all of the spices to make the rub. Get out a small bowl and put all of the blackening spices into it. You'll need to whisk together:
3 tablespoons (21 g) of paprika
1 teaspoon (5.5 g) of salt
1 tablespoons (7 g) of onion powder
1 teaspoon (2 g) of black pepper
1/4 to 1 teaspoon (0.5 to 2 g) of cayenne pepper to taste
1 teaspoon (1.5 g) of thyme
1 teaspoon (1.5 g) of oregano
1/2 teaspoon (1.5 g) of garlic powder Brush the tilapia with olive oil and put it in a pan. Get out 2 pounds (0.91 kg) of tilapia and dip a pastry brush in olive oil. Spread the oil over both sides of the tilapia and lay it in the baking dish or grill basket. The oil will help the blackening rub stick to the fish. Coat the fish with the rub. Sprinkle the blackening seasoning over the fish and then turn it over. Use your hands to rub the seasoning into the fish. If you only want to cook 1 pound (0.45 kg) of tilapia, you won't need to use all of the seasoning. Store the leftover seasoning in an airtight container in the pantry for up to 6 months. Bake the blackened tilapia in the oven or on the grill. If you'd like to bake the fish, place it in a baking dish and cook it at 425 °F (218 °C) for 10 to 12 minutes. If you'd rather grill the fish, put it in a grill basket and set it on a hot grill. Grill the tilapia for 4 minutes, turning it halfway. Refrigerate leftover tilapia in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 or 4 days. Crispy Parmesan Herb Breading Slice the almonds and grate Parmesan cheese. Put 1/3 cup (35 g) of sliced almonds onto a cutting board and chop them finely. Get out a wedge of Parmesan cheese and use a box grater to grate 3 tablespoons (15 g) of cheese. Put the almonds and cheese into a bowl. If you don't have a wedge of cheese, you can use pre-grated cheese but the flavor won't be as intense. Mix the almonds and cheese with bread crumbs and spices. Put 1/4 cup (25 g) of plain dry bread crumbs into the bowl with the cheese and almonds. Then stir in 1/2 teaspoon (1.5 g) of garlic powder, 1/2 teaspoon (3.5 g) of paprika, 1/2 teaspoon (0.2 g) of parsley flakes, and 1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of black pepper. If you don't have bread crumbs, try using crushed crackers. Brush the tilapia with oil and put it in a baking dish. Get out 1 pound (0.45 kg) of tilapia and dip a pastry brush in olive oil. Brush both sides of the fish with the oil. The oil will help the breading stick to the fish. Coat the fish with breading. Lay the fillets into the Parmesan herb breading and turn the pieces over. Ensure that every part of the fillet is covered with the breading. You may need to press gently to get the breading to stick to the fish. Bake the tilapia at 450 °F (232 °C) for 10 to 12 minutes. Place the breaded tilapia into a baking dish and put it in a preheated oven. Bake the fish until the breading becomes crispy and the fish flakes easily with a fork. Store leftover tilapia in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 or 4 days. Keep in mind that it will become soft the longer it's stored. Fresh Herb Seasoning Zest 1 lemon and chop the fresh herbs. Use a microplane or side of a box grater to zest a lemon. Place 3/4 cup (20 g) of fresh herbs on your cutting board and chop them fine. Consider using a mixture of:
Parsley
Thyme
Mint
Chives
Cilantro Mix the herbs, zest, salt, and pepper. Put the lemon zest and chopped herbs into a bowl. Stir in 3/4 teaspoon (4 g) of salt and 1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of black pepper. If you'd like to make the seasoning in advance, put it in an airtight container and freeze it for up to 3 months. Coat the tilapia with the seasoning. Get out 4 tilapia fillets and cover each side with the herb seasoning. Use your fingers to gently press the herbs into the fish. Be gentle as you handle the fish because you don't want it to fall apart. Sauté the fish for 4 minutes. Place the fish in a skillet and pan-fry it over medium heat for 4 minutes. Turn the fish halfway through the cooking time so they cook evenly. Serve the fish immediately with a green salad and crusty bread. If you prefer, place the fish in a baking dish and cook them in the oven instead. Bake the fish at 450 °F (232 °C) for 10 to 12 minutes. Refrigerate the leftover fish in an airtight container for up to 3 or 4 days.
